body: I forgot to say that this pull request has been merged - thanks for closing it.

Besides that the patch looks good to me.

It would also be great to do the thing I've mentioned on the mailing list - let us know if you need any help with implementing that.
Can you please squash all the commits into one so I can merge it into trunk?
Ok, squashed.

Thanks.

Patch has been merged, you can closet his pull request now.

Just curious - do you have any plans to work on a separate driver for RackConnect? If so, feel free to open a new pull request for it (we can re-use the jira ticket LIBCLOUD-389).

Yes, I was just looking at what it would take. I added the wait for the rax_automation_status metadata key to salt-cloud but none of that would be necessary if it were added to the libcloud driver--definitely a better solution.

3. The issue is, apparently, with httplib, this "patch" just tries not to trigger it.

Thanks, but as noted on JIRA (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-390#comment-13757164) this shouldn't be needed, because the actual root cause of this issue has been fixed in trunk.
Ah, still for 2, we use salt-cloud which uses libcloud with rackspace, we just spin VM's up and randomly, we hit that 104 error.
The link I added in the initial comment has additional data

Thanks for the additional info. Tomorrow, I'll check if salt-cloud does something funky which could cause this.

As far as the link goes - it didn't load in the morning when I initially checked it, but it does load now. The post appears to be from 2008 and you are running 2.6.6 which has been released in 2010. I would be surprised if there was an issue in CPython which hasn't been fixed by then.

In any case, I'll also wait for @alex, I'm sure he has some good insight.
I'm a salt-cloud dev, let me know if you need additional info. We're not doin' anything magical with GIL either ;)

For some reason second part didn't want to apply cleanly so I just manually made changes in the second commit.

``` bash

   /w/lc/libcloud/.git/rebase-apply/patch
When you have resolved this problem, run "git am --continue".
If you prefer to skip this patch, run "git am --skip" instead.
```

I've made some changes that I'll be pushing up soon. I've modelled it to be more like the EC2 driver, which allows the ElasticHostsDriver to work for any region but still be backwards compatible. 

Just thought I'd let you know I'm still working on this
@bennettaur Sounds good. Ping me once you push those changes and I'll have a look.

Thanks for the comments, I should be able to address most of them today. A couple of notes:
- Like you, I wasn't happy with the way that various exceptions were being handled, so I re-wrote the exception handling in a separate branch last week which addresses several of the issues that you noted (including that MalformedResponseError for missing zones that occurred because one of the zones was in a weird state the week before last, and moving it into the Response class).  I'll merge that branch in today (but squash the commits).
- Thanks for the heads-up about the dictionary ordering thing.  I'm actually already aware of that, since I've used previous versions of Python where the randomization has been turned on.  I'm surprised I let any of those slip through, but I'll track them down and get them fixed.
Btw, this patch has been merged so you can close the pr.
Sounds good. Thanks!

@s0undt3ch I've talked to Alex on the IRC and he said this issue doesn't ring any bells, but a bunch of things which could potentially cause this to happen in the older versions have been fixed in 2.7.

We both agreed that a reasonable thing would be to only run this code under Python <= 2.6. 

One thing we would also like to know is if we can decrease the sleep interval even further (e.g. `time.sleep(0.001)`) and see if it still helps - can you please test this out?

```
[20:12] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: hey, have you had a chance to look at ] [ ilgiz    ] [ kandinski   ] [ polvi          ] 
[20:12] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/141
[20:12] <       Kami_> | well that was a #failpaste
[20:28] <Alex_Gaynor> | Kami_: I hadn't, looking now
[20:29] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: thanks
[20:34] <Alex_Gaynor> | Kami_: hmm, this issue doesn't ring any bells, I know that a bunch of signals/ssl/random stuff has been fixed 
                      in 2.7, and I see this 2.6; I wonder if it's related
[20:35] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: hm, ok
[20:35] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: do you think it would be reasonable to include his patch and only use it if python <= 2.6?
[20:36] <Alex_Gaynor> | Kami_: I think that's maybe the best idea, can we use an even shorter sleep duration?
[20:36] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: since they use this code in salt-cloud and I would imagine a lot of ppl still use older distros 
          which ship with 2.6
[20:36] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: yeah, I was thinking about the same thing (shorter sleep duration)
[20:37] <       Kami_> | Alex_Gaynor: i'll add a comment to the ticket and ask if the person can try to decrease it and see if it 
          still helps
```
thanks
This issue was presented to me under python 2.6. Unfortunately, I'm unable to stress test this issue under python 2.7, however, I'll lower the sleep to the value you asked and see how it goes.

@bennettaur Sounds good, I'll have a look shortly.

@bennettaur As far as the tests go - none of our tests actually connect to the provider endpoint. We use fixture system which returns mocked responses which are stored in files.

To test this, I would do something along those lines for every region:
1. Instantiate a driver for region A
2. Assert that `driver.connection.host` equals host for the provided region
3. Ideally you would also use a mocked `connectionCls` and make sure the `connectionCls` constructor gets passed the correct `host` argument. 

Third step would like something along those lines:

``` python
connectionCls = Mock()
Driver.connectionCls.conn_classes = (connectionCls, connectionCls)
driver = Driver(...)
call_kwargs = connectionCls.call_args[1]
self.assertEqual(call_kwargs['host'], actual_region_host)
```

To make sure host is correctly preserved I would also do that:
1. Test for region A
2. Test for region B
3. Test for region A (make sure host is still set correctly)

Nice. I thought it was going to be much harder than this to do 'right', but this is straightforward and pragmatic. And if you were using the constants in your coded properly then its an entirely backwards compatible change.

Still worth a mention in the changelog in case anyone has code that depends on a number somehow?

Otherwise, big +1 from me.
@Jc2k Yeah, I've updated the CHANGES file - 8475777c92756be18dacc2dca352747de732175b. I also plan to update the "Upgrade notes page" before releasing a new version.
@s0undt3ch bumping again since two days have passed.  I'll also be working on a new release today and if everything looks OK, I'd like to include this fix.
Merged it into trunk.

Ok, so, I have bad and good news.

The good news is, right now, there's no need to wait for me any more.
The bad news is that I've removed the sleep completely from the code for the past 3 days. No issues. Meaning, my PR is not needed and I've failed to find the point of failure.

Ultimately, you decide, but I think it's best not to include my fix since I'm now unable to get it to fail again meaning libcloud would have an unnecessary sleep on it's code, not cool.

Reviewing this a little more, I renamed the ElasticHostsBaseNodeDriver to just be ElasticHostsNodeDriver, which could break backwards compatibility for anyone using the BaseNodeDriver to connect to the default 'us-1' region. Not sure if this is a concern of yours or not.

I can't commit time to writing the tests right now, but I will as soon as I am able to.

Sorry, what do You mean at "please squash all the commits into a single on"? I'm new in pull requests and don't know what is and how :(

@gigimon I mean merging all the commits into one.

This can be achieved using git rebase and squash - http://gitready.com/advanced/2009/02/10/squashing-commits-with-rebase.html

Basically, you want to do:

git rebase -i <sha revision of the parent of your first commit>
type s or squash for all the commits except the first one
update commit message
done!
Complete, all in one commit, Thank You for help!
